root.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1968. The Central and South New Guinea Phylum: a report on the language situation in south New Guinea, Papers in New Guinea Linguistics No. 8, vol. Series A-16, 1-17. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.
root.pri-name: South and Central New Guinea Phylum
root.geography: spoken in the plains of South New Guinea, stretching from Etna Bay in the west to the Papuan Gulf in the east, as well as in a portion of the highlands in the interior of New Guinea and a number of the islands in the Torres Straits.

child.pub-comments: "For further counts, Aghu has been selected to represent the subgroup. It seems to be relatively free of borrowings from the surrounding non-Awyu languages" (Voorhoeve 1968:4).

child.pub-comments: "The Ok languages […] appear to constitute a major subgroup of the much larger Asmat-Awyu-Ok family, within which they have their closest relationship with Asmat" (Voorhoeve 1968:4). For more information about the internal relationships within the Ok family, see Healey 1964.

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1968. The Central and South New Guinea Phylum: a report on the language situation in south New Guinea, Papers in New Guinea Linguistics No. 8, vol. Series A-16, 1-17. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.tree-val: South and Central New Guinea Phylum: Voorhoeve 1968

child.pub-comments: "Drabbe (1953) distinguishes six dialects within Kamoro but only in one of these, the Tarya dialect, he published sufficient lexical material to allow lexicostatistical comparisons to be made" (Voorhoeve 1968:4).

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1968. The Central and South New Guinea Phylum: a report on the language situation in south New Guinea, Papers in New Guinea Linguistics No. 8, vol. Series A-16, 1-17. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.tree-val: South and Central New Guinea Phylum: Voorhoeve 1968

child.pub-comments: "Within Asmat five dialects can be distinguished (Drabbe 1963). They all share approximately 90% cognates" (Voorhoeve 1968:4). For more information about Asmat dialects, see Drabbe 1959a and 1959b, and Voorhoeve 1965.

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1968. The Central and South New Guinea Phylum: a report on the language situation in south New Guinea, Papers in New Guinea Linguistics No. 8, vol. Series A-16, 1-17. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.
child.tree-val: South and Central New Guinea Phylum: Voorhoeve 1968
child.pub-comments: A family-level isolate. "Mombum is a border case; its closest relationship is with Asmat. Since it does not show comparably close links with any other language it has been provisionally included in the Asmat-Awyu-Ok family" (Voorhoeve 1968:4).

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1968. The Central and South New Guinea Phylum: a report on the language situation in south New Guinea, Papers in New Guinea Linguistics No. 8, vol. Series A-16, 1-17. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.
child.geography: spoken in the Nomad area between the Strickland River and the Southern Highlands

child.pub-comments: "Because of the limited size of the Awin word lists it cannot be clearly established whether West awin and East Awin constitute dialects or separate languages" (Voorhoeve 1968:6).

child.pub-comments: In this paper, Gawir was used for the lexicostatistical counts representing South-east Marind (Voorhoeve 1968:5).
Including Gawir, South-east Marind has four dialects (Voorhoeve 1968:5).

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1968. The Central and South New Guinea Phylum: a report on the language situation in south New Guinea, Papers in New Guinea Linguistics No. 8, vol. Series A-16, 1-17. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.tree-val: South and Central New Guinea Phylum: Voorhoeve 1968
child.pub-comments: "Boazi hovers on the borderline of family and stock but has been included in the family because it shares with Yaqay and Marind a feature of verb structure which set them off from the surrounding languages: 'The subject-index precedes the base' (Boelaars 1950, p.200)" (Voorhoeve 1968:5).

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1968. The Central and South New Guinea Phylum: a report on the language situation in south New Guinea, Papers in New Guinea Linguistics No. 8, vol. Series A-16, 1-17. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.tree-val: South and Central New Guinea Phylum: Voorhoeve 1968
child.pub-comments: "None of these [i.e. Fasu, Gogodala, Tirio, Agöb, Miriam] seems to have lower level relationships with any other language" (Voorhoeve 1968:7).

child.pub-comments: "The only lexical data on these languages published so far is the short word list of the Moutn Goliath language collected by De Kock (1912)" (Voorhoeve 1968:10).

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1968. The Central and South New Guinea Phylum: a report on the language situation in south New Guinea, Papers in New Guinea Linguistics No. 8, vol. Series A-16, 1-17. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.
child.tree-val: South and Central New Guinea Phylum: Voorhoeve 1968

child.pub-comments: "De Kock's word list is too short to allow calculation of meaningful percentages, but the indications of genetic relationship with Teléfól, Kaeti and Asmat appear to be clear enough to warrant the inclusion of the Mount Goliath language - and consequently, of the Goliath family - in the South and West New Guine Phlyum" (Voorhoeve 1968:10). For more information about the Goliath family, see Bromley 1967.

child.publications: Voorhoeve, C L. 1968. The Central and South New Guinea Phylum: a report on the language situation in south New Guinea, Papers in New Guinea Linguistics No. 8, vol. Series A-16, 1-17. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.

child.pub-comments: "Yey, Kanum and Moraori, bordering on South-east Marind in the east, seem to form one stock. However, the percentages may be inflated by shared borrowings from South-east Marind" (Voorhoeve 1968:8).
